subject: Call of Cthulhu, now in modern HTML
msgSnippet: I wanted to read the writings of Mr. Thurston, but I ve never been a huge fan of reading things in PDF. To this end, I ve converted (through copy/paste and
messageBody:
I wanted to read the writings of Mr. Thurston, but I've never been a huge fan of reading things in PDF. To this end, I've converted (through copy/paste and some linebreak changes) tim_rice09's PDF into modern HTML/CSS, and have posted my work to <https://github.com/adiabatic/qs-literature>. The actual page you're probably interested in is <http://adiabatic.github.com/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/>.

An excerpt from the README, pasted here:

> This repository contains literature written in Quickscript, an alternate orthography for English.
>
> At this point the one thing you’ll probably want to look at is The Call of Cthulhu, originally posted to the mailing list by tim_rice09. It’s set in a Unicode-enabled version of Kingsley, a Junior Quickscript font thanks to the magic of @font-face.
>
> This version has a number of changes to the posted PDF:
>
> • It’s in HTML, not PDF, for easier changes
> • line lengths are shortened (the initial line is only 65 characters long instead of a whopping 97 in the original)
> • paragraphs are indented
> • there’s space between paragraphs
> • «" blah» has been changed to «"blah» in multiple places

If you're interested in the mechanics of this, I/Github Pages use(s) Jekyll to convert Markdown-formatted text to HTML.
